description.para: The class Triangulation_3 defines the following types:

memberdef.definition: typedef Traits CGAL::Triangulation_3< Traits, TDS, SLDS >::Geom_traits
memberdef.name: Geom_traits

memberdef.definition: typedef TDS CGAL::Triangulation_3< Traits, TDS, SLDS >::Triangulation_data_structure
memberdef.name: Triangulation_data_structure

memberdef.definition: typedef SLDS CGAL::Triangulation_3< Traits, TDS, SLDS >::Lock_data_structure
memberdef.name: Lock_data_structure

memberdef.definition: typedef Geom_traits::Segment_3 CGAL::Triangulation_3< Traits, TDS, SLDS >::Segment
memberdef.name: Segment

memberdef.definition: typedef Geom_traits::Triangle_3 CGAL::Triangulation_3< Traits, TDS, SLDS >::Triangle
memberdef.name: Triangle

memberdef.definition: typedef Geom_traits::Tetrahedron_3 CGAL::Triangulation_3< Traits, TDS, SLDS >::Tetrahedron
memberdef.name: Tetrahedron

description.para: Only vertices (0-faces) and cells (3-faces) are stored.
Edges (1-faces) and facets (2-faces) are not explicitly represented and thus there are no corresponding classes (see Section Representation).

memberdef.definition: typedef Triangulation_data_structure::Vertex CGAL::Triangulation_3< Traits, TDS, SLDS >::Vertex
memberdef.name: Vertex

memberdef.definition: typedef Triangulation_data_structure::Cell CGAL::Triangulation_3< Traits, TDS, SLDS >::Cell
memberdef.name: Cell

memberdef.definition: typedef Triangulation_data_structure::Facet CGAL::Triangulation_3< Traits, TDS, SLDS >::Facet
memberdef.name: Facet

memberdef.definition: typedef Triangulation_data_structure::Edge CGAL::Triangulation_3< Traits, TDS, SLDS >::Edge
memberdef.name: Edge

description.para: The vertices and faces of the triangulations are accessed through handles, iterators and circulators.

A handle is a model of the Handle concept, and supports the two dereference operators and operator->. A circulator is a model of the concept Circulator. Iterators and circulators are bidirectional and non-mutable. The edges and facets of the triangulation can also be visited through iterators and circulators which are bidirectional and non-mutable. Iterators and circulators are convertible to the corresponding handles, thus the user can pass them directly as arguments to the functions. The handles are also model of the concepts LessThanComparable and Hashable, that is they can be used as keys in containers such as std::map and boost::unordered_map.

briefdescription.para: handle to a vertex

memberdef.definition: typedef Triangulation_data_structure::Cell_handle CGAL::Triangulation_3< Traits, TDS, SLDS >::Cell_handle
memberdef.name: Cell_handle

briefdescription.para: handle to a cell

memberdef.definition: typedef Triangulation_simplex_3<Self> CGAL::Triangulation_3< Traits, TDS, SLDS >::Simplex
memberdef.name: Simplex

briefdescription.para: Reference to a simplex (vertex, edge, facet or cell) of the triangulation.

memberdef.definition: typedef Triangulation_data_structure::size_type CGAL::Triangulation_3< Traits, TDS, SLDS >::size_type
memberdef.name: size_type

briefdescription.para: Size type (an unsigned integral type)
Difference type (a signed integral type)
iterator over cells
iterator over facets
iterator over edges
iterator over vertices

briefdescription.para: iterator over the points corresponding to the finite vertices of the triangulation.
circulator over all cells incident to a given edge
circulator over all facets incident to a given edge
Concurrency tag (from the TDS).
Introduces a triangulation t having only one vertex which is the infinite vertex.

detaileddescription.para: lock_ds is an optional pointer to the lock data structure for parallel operations. It must be provided if concurrency is enabled.

briefdescription.para: Same as the previous one, but with parameters in reverse order.
Copy constructor.

detaileddescription.para: All vertices and faces are duplicated. The pointer to the lock data structure is not copied. Thus, the copy won't be concurrency-safe as long as the user has not call Triangulation_3::set_lock_data_structure.

memberdef.argsstring: (InputIterator first, InputIterator last, const Geom_traits &traits=Geom_traits(), Lock_data_structure *lock_ds=NULL)
memberdef.name: Triangulation_3

briefdescription.para: Equivalent to constructing an empty triangulation with the optional traits class argument and calling insert(first,last).
The triangulation tr is duplicated, and modifying the copy after the duplication does not modify the original.

detaileddescription.para: The previous triangulation held by t is deleted.

briefdescription.para: The triangulations tr and t are swapped.

detaileddescription.para: t.swap(tr) should be preferred to t = tr or to t(tr) if tr is deleted after that. Indeed, there is no copy of cells and vertices, thus this method runs in constant time.

briefdescription.para: Deletes all finite vertices and all cells of t.

memberdef.argsstring: (const Triangulation_3< GT, Tds1 > &t1, const Triangulation_3< GT, Tds2 > &t2)
memberdef.name: operator==

briefdescription.para: Equality operator.

detaileddescription.para: Returns true iff there exist a bijection between the vertices of t1 and those of t2 and a bijection between the cells of t1 and those of t2, which preserve the geometry of the triangulation, that is, the points of each corresponding pair of vertices are equal, and the tetrahedra corresponding to each pair of cells are equal (up to a permutation of their vertices).

memberdef.argsstring: (const Triangulation_3< GT, Tds1 > &t1, const Triangulation_3< GT, Tds2 > &t2)
memberdef.name: operator!=

briefdescription.para: The opposite of operator==.

memberdef.definition: const Geom_traits& CGAL::Triangulation_3< Traits, TDS, SLDS >::geom_traits
memberdef.name: geom_traits

briefdescription.para: Returns a const reference to the geometric traits object.

memberdef.definition: const Triangulation_data_structure& CGAL::Triangulation_3< Traits, TDS, SLDS >::tds
memberdef.name: tds

briefdescription.para: Returns a const reference to the triangulation data structure.
Returns a reference to the triangulation data structure.

detaileddescription.para: This method is mainly a help for users implementing their own triangulation algorithms. The responsibility of keeping a valid triangulation belongs to the user when using advanced operations allowing a direct manipulation of the tds.

briefdescription.para: Returns the dimension of the affine hull.
Returns the number of finite vertices.
Returns the number of cells or 0 if t.dimension() < 3.
Returns the infinite vertex.
This is an advanced function.

detaileddescription.para: This method is meant to be used only if you have done a low-level operation on the underlying tds that invalidated the infinite vertex. Sets the infinite vertex.

briefdescription.para: Returns a cell incident to the infinite vertex.

description.para: As previously said, the triangulation is a collection of cells that are either infinite or represent a finite tetrahedra, where an infinite cell is a cell incident to the infinite vertex.
Similarly we call an edge (resp. facet) infinite if it is incident to the infinite vertex.

briefdescription.para: The number of facets.

detaileddescription.para: Returns 0 if t.dimension() < 2.

briefdescription.para: The number of edges.

detaileddescription.para: Returns 0 if t.dimension() < 1.

briefdescription.para: The number of finite cells.

detaileddescription.para: Returns 0 if t.dimension() < 3.

briefdescription.para: The number of finite facets.

detaileddescription.para: Returns 0 if t.dimension() < 2.

briefdescription.para: The number of finite edges.

detaileddescription.para: Returns 0 if t.dimension() < 1.

briefdescription.para: Returns the tetrahedron formed by the four vertices of c.

simplesect.para: t.dimension() == 3 and the cell is finite.

briefdescription.para: Returns the triangle formed by the three vertices of facet (c,i).

detaileddescription.para:
The triangle is oriented so that its normal points to the inside of cell c.
t.dimension() $ \geq2$ and $ i \in\{0,1,2,3\}$ in dimension 3, $ i = 3$ in dimension 2, and the facet is finite.

briefdescription.para: Same as the previous method for facet f.

simplesect.para: t.dimension() $ \geq2$ and the facet is finite.

briefdescription.para: Returns the line segment formed by the vertices of e.

simplesect.para: t.dimension() $ \geq1$ and e is finite.

memberdef.argsstring: (Cell_handle c, int i, int j) const
memberdef.name: segment

briefdescription.para: Same as the previous method for edge (c,i,j).

simplesect.para: As above and $ i\neq j$. Moreover $ i,j \in\{0,1,2,3\}$ in dimension 3, $ i,j \in\{0,1,2\}$ in dimension 2, $ i,j \in\{0,1\}$ in dimension 1, and the edge is finite.

memberdef.definition: const Point& CGAL::Triangulation_3< Traits, TDS, SLDS >::point
memberdef.name: point

briefdescription.para: Returns the point given by vertex i of cell c.

simplesect.para: t.dimension() $ \geq0$ and $ i \in\{0,1,2,3\}$ in dimension 3, $ i \in\{0,1,2\}$ in dimension 2, $ i \in\{0,1\}$ in dimension 1, $ i = 0$ in dimension 0, and the vertex is finite.

memberdef.definition: const Point& CGAL::Triangulation_3< Traits, TDS, SLDS >::point
memberdef.name: point

briefdescription.para: Same as the previous method for vertex v.

simplesect.para: t.dimension() $ \geq0$ and the vertex is finite.

sectiondef.header: Tests for Finite and Infinite Vertices and Faces

briefdescription.para: true, iff vertex v is the infinite vertex.
true, iff c is incident to the infinite vertex.

simplesect.para: t.dimension() == 3.

briefdescription.para: true, iff the facet i of cell c is incident to the infinite vertex.

simplesect.para: t.dimension() $ \geq2$ and $ i\in\{0,1,2,3\}$ in dimension 3, $ i=3$ in dimension 2.

briefdescription.para: true iff facet f is incident to the infinite vertex.

simplesect.para: t.dimension() $ \geq2$.

memberdef.argsstring: (Cell_handle c, int i, int j) const
memberdef.name: is_infinite

briefdescription.para: true, iff the edge (i,j) of cell c is incident to the infinite vertex.

simplesect.para: t.dimension() $ \geq1$ and $ i\neq j$. Moreover $ i,j \in\{0,1,2,3\}$ in dimension 3, $ i,j \in\{0,1,2\}$ in dimension 2, $ i,j \in\{0,1\}$ in dimension 1.

briefdescription.para: true iff edge e is incident to the infinite vertex.

simplesect.para: t.dimension() $ \geq1$.

briefdescription.para: Tests whether p is a vertex of t by locating p in the triangulation.

detaileddescription.para: If p is found, the associated vertex v is given.

briefdescription.para: Tests whether v is a vertex of t.

memberdef.argsstring: (Vertex_handle u, Vertex_handle v, Cell_handle &c, int &i, int &j) const
memberdef.name: is_edge

briefdescription.para: Tests whether (u,v) is an edge of t.

detaileddescription.para:
If the edge is found, it gives a cell c having this edge and the indices i and j of the vertices u and v in c, in this order.
u and v are vertices of t.

memberdef.argsstring: (Vertex_handle u, Vertex_handle v, Vertex_handle w, Cell_handle &c, int &i, int &j, int &k) const
memberdef.name: is_facet

briefdescription.para: Tests whether (u,v,w) is a facet of t.

detaileddescription.para:
If the facet is found, it computes a cell c having this facet and the indices i, j and k of the vertices u, v and w in c, in this order.
u, v and w are vertices of t.

briefdescription.para: Tests whether c is a cell of t.

memberdef.argsstring: (Vertex_handle u, Vertex_handle v, Vertex_handle w, Vertex_handle x, Cell_handle &c, int &i, int &j, int &k, int &l) const
memberdef.name: is_cell

briefdescription.para: Tests whether (u,v,w,x) is a cell of t.

detaileddescription.para:
If the cell c is found, the method computes the indices i, j, k and l of the vertices u, v, w and x in c, in this order.
u, v, w and x are vertices of t.

memberdef.argsstring: (Vertex_handle u, Vertex_handle v, Vertex_handle w, Vertex_handle x, Cell_handle &c) const
memberdef.name: is_cell

briefdescription.para: Tests whether (u,v,w,x) is a cell of t and computes this cell c.

simplesect.para: u, v, w and x are vertices of t.

description.para: There is a method has_vertex() in the cell class.
The analogous methods for facets are defined here.

briefdescription.para: If v is a vertex of f, then j is the index of v in the cell f.first, and the method returns true.

memberdef.argsstring: (Cell_handle c, int i, Vertex_handle v, int &j) const
memberdef.name: has_vertex

briefdescription.para: Same for facet (c,i).

detaileddescription.para: Computes the index j of v in c.

memberdef.argsstring: (Cell_handle c, int i, Vertex_handle v) const
memberdef.name: has_vertex

briefdescription.para: Same as the first two methods, but these two methods do not return the index of the vertex.

description.para: The following three methods test whether two facets have the same vertices.

memberdef.argsstring: (Cell_handle c, int i, Cell_handle n, int j) const
memberdef.name: are_equal

memberdef.argsstring: (const Facet &f, Cell_handle n, int j) const
memberdef.name: are_equal

briefdescription.para: For these three methods:

simplesect.para: t.dimension() == 3.

description.para: The class Triangulation_3 provides two functions to locate a given point with respect to a triangulation.
It provides also functions to test if a given point is inside a finite face or not. Note that the class Delaunay_triangulation_3 also provides a nearest_vertex() function.

briefdescription.para: If the point query lies inside the convex hull of the points, the cell that contains the query in its interior is returned.

detaileddescription.para: If query lies on a facet, an edge or on a vertex, one of the cells having query on its boundary is returned.

If the point query lies outside the convex hull of the points, an infinite cell with vertices $ \{ p, q, r, \infty\}$ is returned such that the tetrahedron $ ( p, q, r, query )$ is positively oriented (the rest of the triangulation lies on the other side of facet $ ( p, q, r )$).
Note that locate works even in degenerate dimensions: in dimension 2 (resp. 1, 0) the Cell_handle returned is the one that represents the facet (resp. edge, vertex) containing the query point.
The optional argument start is used as a starting place for the search.

The optional argument could_lock_zone is used by the concurrency-safe version of the triangulation. When the pointer is not null, the locate will try to lock all the cells along the walk. If it succeeds, *could_lock_zone is true, otherwise it is false. In any case, the locked cells are not unlocked by locate, leaving this choice to the user.

briefdescription.para: Same as above but uses hint as the starting place for the search.
Same as locate() but uses inexact predicates.

detaileddescription.para: This function returns a handle on a cell that is a good approximation of the exact location of query, while being faster. Note that it may return a handle on a cell whose interior does not contain query. When the triangulation has dimension smaller than 3, start is returned.
Note that this function is available only if the cartesian coordinates of query are accessible with functions x(), y() and z().

memberdef.argsstring: (const Point &query, Locate_type &lt, int &li, int &lj, Cell_handle start=Cell_handle(), bool *could_lock_zone=NULL) const
memberdef.name: locate

briefdescription.para: If query lies inside the affine hull of the points, the $ k$-face (finite or infinite) that contains query in its interior is returned, by means of the cell returned together with lt, which is set to the locate type of the query (VERTEX, EDGE, FACET, CELL, or OUTSIDE_CONVEX_HULL if the cell is infinite and query lies strictly in it) and two indices li and lj that specify the $ k$-face of the cell containing query.

detaileddescription.para: If the $ k$-face is a cell, li and lj have no meaning; if it is a facet (resp. vertex), li gives the index of the facet (resp. vertex) and lj has no meaning; if it is and edge, li and lj give the indices of its vertices.

If the point query lies outside the affine hull of the points, which can happen in case of degenerate dimensions, lt is set to OUTSIDE_AFFINE_HULL, and the cell returned has no meaning. As a particular case, if there is no finite vertex yet in the triangulation, lt is set to OUTSIDE_AFFINE_HULL and locate returns the default constructed handle.
The optional argument start is used as a starting place for the search.

The optional argument could_lock_zone is used by the concurrency-safe version of the triangulation. When the pointer is not null, the locate will try to lock all the cells along the walk. If it succeeds, *could_lock_zone is true, otherwise it is false. In any case, the locked cells are not unlocked by locate, leaving this choice to the user.

memberdef.argsstring: (const Point &query, Locate_type &lt, int &li, int &lj, Vertex_handle hint, bool *could_lock_zone=NULL) const
memberdef.name: locate

briefdescription.para: Same as above but uses hint as the starting place for the search.

memberdef.argsstring: (const Point &p, Cell_handle c, Locate_type &lt, int &li, int &lj) const
memberdef.name: side_of_cell

briefdescription.para: Returns a value indicating on which side of the oriented boundary of c the point p lies.

detaileddescription.para: More precisely, it returns:

listitem.para: ON_BOUNDED_SIDE if p is inside the cell. For an infinite cell this means that p lies strictly in the half space limited by its finite facet and not containing any other point of the triangulation.

ON_BOUNDARY if p on the boundary of the cell. For an infinite cell this means that p lies on the finite facet. Then lt together with li and lj give the precise location on the boundary. (See the descriptions of the locate methods.)

ON_UNBOUNDED_SIDE if p lies outside the cell. For an infinite cell this means that p does not satisfy either of the two previous conditions.
t.dimension() == 3

memberdef.argsstring: (const Point &p, const Facet &f, Locate_type &lt, int &li, int &lj) const
memberdef.name: side_of_facet

briefdescription.para: Returns a value indicating on which side of the oriented boundary of f the point p lies:

listitem.para: ON_BOUNDED_SIDE if p is inside the facet. For an infinite facet this means that p lies strictly in the half plane limited by its finite edge and not containing any other point of the triangulation .

ON_BOUNDARY if p is on the boundary of the facet. For an infinite facet this means that p lies on the finite edge. lt, li and lj give the precise location of p on the boundary of the facet. li and lj refer to indices in the degenerate cell c representing f.
ON_UNBOUNDED_SIDE if p lies outside the facet. For an infinite facet this means that p does not satisfy either of the two previous conditions.

simplesect.para: t.dimension() == 2 and p lies in the plane containing the triangulation. f.second $ =3$ (in dimension 2 there is only one facet per cell).

memberdef.argsstring: (const Point &p, Cell_handle c, Locate_type &lt, int &li, int &lj) const
memberdef.name: side_of_facet

briefdescription.para: Same as the previous method for the facet (c,3).

memberdef.argsstring: (const Point &p, const Edge &e, Locate_type &lt, int &li) const
memberdef.name: side_of_edge

briefdescription.para: Returns a value indicating on which side of the oriented boundary of e the point p lies:

listitem.para: ON_BOUNDED_SIDE if p is inside the edge. For an infinite edge this means that p lies in the half line defined by the vertex and not containing any other point of the triangulation.
ON_BOUNDARY if p equals one of the vertices, li give the index of the vertex in the cell storing e

ON_UNBOUNDED_SIDE if p lies outside the edge. For an infinite edge this means that p lies on the other half line, which contains the other points of the triangulation.
t.dimension() == 1 and p is collinear with the points of the triangulation. e.second == 0 and e.third $ =1$ (in dimension 1 there is only one edge per cell).

memberdef.argsstring: (const Point &p, Cell_handle c, Locate_type &lt, int &li) const
memberdef.name: side_of_edge

briefdescription.para: Same as the previous method for edge $ (c,0,1)$.

description.para: Two kinds of flips exist for a three-dimensional triangulation.

They are reciprocal. To be flipped, an edge must be incident to three tetrahedra. During the flip, these three tetrahedra disappear and two tetrahedra appear. fig__Triangulation3figflips (left) shows the edge that is flipped as bold dashed, and one of its three incident facets is shaded. On the right, the facet shared by the two new tetrahedra is shaded. Flips are possible only under the following conditions: - the edge or facet to be flipped is not on the boundary of the convex hull of the triangulation - the five points involved are in convex position.
fig__Triangulation3figflips Flips
The following methods guarantee the validity of the resulting 3D triangulation. Flips for a 2d triangulation are not implemented yet.

briefdescription.para: Before flipping, these methods check that edge e=(c,i,j) is flippable (which is quite expensive).

detaileddescription.para: They return false or true according to this test.

briefdescription.para: Should be preferred to the previous methods when the edge is known to be flippable.

simplesect.para: The edge is flippable.

briefdescription.para: Before flipping, these methods check that facet f=(c,i) is flippable (which is quite expensive).

detaileddescription.para: They return false or true according to this test.

briefdescription.para: Should be preferred to the previous methods when the facet is known to be flippable.

simplesect.para: The facet is flippable.

description.para: The following operations are guaranteed to lead to a valid triangulation when they are applied on a valid triangulation.

briefdescription.para: Inserts the point p in the triangulation and returns the corresponding vertex.

detaileddescription.para: If point p coincides with an already existing vertex, this vertex is returned and the triangulation remains unchanged.

If point p lies in the convex hull of the points, it is added naturally: if it lies inside a cell, the cell is split into four cells, if it lies on a facet, the two incident cells are split into three cells, if it lies on an edge, all the cells incident to this edge are split into two cells.

If point p is strictly outside the convex hull but in the affine hull, p is linked to all visible points on the convex hull to form the new triangulation. See Figure Triangulation3figinsert_outside_convex_hull.

If point p is outside the affine hull of the points, p is linked to all the points, and the dimension of the triangulation is incremented. All the points now belong to the boundary of the convex hull, so, the infinite vertex is linked to all the points to triangulate the new infinite face. See Figure Triangulation3figinsert_outside_affine_hull. The optional argument start is used as a starting place for the search.

briefdescription.para: Same as above but uses hint as the starting place for the search.

memberdef.argsstring: (const Point &p, Locate_type lt, Cell_handle loc, int li, int lj)
memberdef.name: insert

briefdescription.para: Inserts the point p in the triangulation and returns the corresponding vertex.

detaileddescription.para: Similar to the above insert() function, but takes as additional parameter the return values of a previous location query. See description of locate() above.

briefdescription.para: Inserts the points in the range [first,last).

detaileddescription.para:
Returns the number of inserted points. Note that this function is not guaranteed to insert the points following the order of InputIterator.
InputIterator
must be an input iterator with value type Point.

description.para: We also provide some other methods that can be used instead of Triangulatation_3::insert() when the place where the new point must be inserted is already known.
They are also guaranteed to lead to a valid triangulation when they are applied on a valid triangulation.

briefdescription.para: Inserts the point p in the cell c.

detaileddescription.para:
The cell c is split into 4 tetrahedra.
t.dimension() == 3 and p lies strictly inside cell c.

briefdescription.para: Inserts the point p in the facet f.

detaileddescription.para:
In dimension 3, the 2 neighboring cells are split into 3 tetrahedra; in dimension 2, the facet is split into 3 triangles.
t.dimension() $ \geq2$ and p lies strictly inside face f.

briefdescription.para: As above, insertion in the facet (c,i).

simplesect.para: As above and $ i \in\{0,1,2,3\}$ in dimension 3, $ i = 3$ in dimension 2.

briefdescription.para: Inserts p in the edge e.

detaileddescription.para:
In dimension 3, all the cells having this edge are split into 2 tetrahedra; in dimension 2, the 2 neighboring facets are split into 2 triangles; in dimension 1, the edge is split into 2 edges.
t.dimension() $ \geq1$ and p lies on edge e.

memberdef.argsstring: (const Point &p, Cell_handle c, int i, int j)
memberdef.name: insert_in_edge

briefdescription.para: As above, inserts p in the edge $ (i, j)$ of c.

simplesect.para: As above and $ i\neq j$. Moreover $ i,j \in\{0,1,2,3\}$ in dimension 3, $ i,j \in\{0,1,2\}$ in dimension 2, $ i,j \in\{0,1\}$ in dimension 1.

briefdescription.para: The cell c must be an infinite cell containing p.

detaileddescription.para:
Links p to all points in the triangulation that are visible from p. Updates consequently the infinite faces. See Figure Triangulation3figinsert_outside_convex_hull.
t.dimension() > 0, c, and the $ k$-face represented by c is infinite and contains t. insert_outside_convex_hull() (2-dimensional case) insert_outside_convex_hull() (2-dimensional case)

briefdescription.para: p is linked to all the points, and the infinite vertex is linked to all the points (including p) to triangulate the new infinite face, so that all the points now belong to the boundary of the convex hull.

detaileddescription.para: See Figure Triangulation3figinsert_outside_affine_hull.

This method can be used to insert the first point in an empty triangulation.
t.dimension() < 3 and p lies outside the affine hull of the points. insert_outside_affine_hull() (2-dimensional case) insert_outside_affine_hull() (2-dimensional case)

memberdef.argsstring: (const Point &p, CellIt cell_begin, CellIt cell_end, Cell_handle begin, int i)
memberdef.name: insert_in_hole

briefdescription.para: Creates a new vertex by starring a hole.

detaileddescription.para: It takes an iterator range [cell_begin,cell_end) of Cell_handles which specifies a hole: a set of connected cells (resp. facets in dimension 2) which is star-shaped wrt p. (begin, i) is a facet (resp. an edge) on the boundary of the hole, that is, begin belongs to the set of cells (resp. facets) previously described, and begin->neighbor(i) does not. Then this function deletes all the cells (resp. facets) describing the hole, creates a new vertex v, and for each facet (resp. edge) on the boundary of the hole, creates a new cell (resp. facet) with v as vertex. Then v->set_point(p) is called and v is returned.

This operation is equivalent to calling tds().insert_in_hole(cell_begin, cell_end, begin, i); v->set_point(p).
t.dimension() $ \geq2$, the set of cells (resp. facets in dimension 2) is connected, its boundary is connected, and p lies inside the hole, which is star-shaped wrt p.

memberdef.argsstring: (const Point &p, CellIt cell_begin, CellIt cell_end, Cell_handle begin, int i, Vertex_handle newv)
memberdef.name: insert_in_hole

briefdescription.para: Same as above, except that newv will be used as the new vertex, which must have been allocated previously with e.g. create_vertex.

sectiondef.header: Cell, Face, Edge and Vertex Iterators

description.para: The following iterators allow the user to visit cells, facets, edges and vertices of the triangulation.
These iterators are non-mutable, bidirectional and their value types are respectively Cell, Facet, Edge and Vertex. They are all invalidated by any change in the triangulation.

briefdescription.para: Starts at an arbitrary finite vertex.

detaileddescription.para: Then ++ and -- will iterate over finite vertices. Returns finite_vertices_end() when t.number_of_vertices() == 0.

briefdescription.para: Past-the-end iterator.
Starts at an arbitrary finite edge.

detaileddescription.para: Then ++ and -- will iterate over finite edges. Returns finite_edges_end() when t.dimension() < 1.

briefdescription.para: Past-the-end iterator.
Starts at an arbitrary finite facet.

detaileddescription.para: Then ++ and -- will iterate over finite facets. Returns finite_facets_end() when t.dimension() < 2.

briefdescription.para: Past-the-end iterator.
Starts at an arbitrary finite cell.

detaileddescription.para: Then ++ and -- will iterate over finite cells. Returns finite_cells_end() when t.dimension() < 3.

briefdescription.para: Past-the-end iterator.
Starts at an arbitrary vertex.

detaileddescription.para: Iterates over all vertices (even the infinite one). Returns vertices_end() when t.number_of_vertices() == 0.

briefdescription.para: Past-the-end iterator.
Starts at an arbitrary edge.

detaileddescription.para: Iterates over all edges (even infinite ones). Returns edges_end() when t.dimension() < 1.

briefdescription.para: Past-the-end iterator.
Starts at an arbitrary facet.

detaileddescription.para: Iterates over all facets (even infinite ones). Returns facets_end() when t.dimension() < 2.

briefdescription.para: Past-the-end iterator.
Starts at an arbitrary cell.

detaileddescription.para: Iterates over all cells (even infinite ones). Returns cells_end() when t.dimension() < 3.

briefdescription.para: Past-the-end iterator.
Iterates over the points of the triangulation.
Past-the-end iterator.

description.para: The following circulators respectively visit all cells or all facets incident to a given edge.
They are non-mutable and bidirectional. They are invalidated by any modification of one of the cells traversed.

briefdescription.para: Starts at an arbitrary cell incident to e.

simplesect.para: t.dimension() == 3.

memberdef.argsstring: (Cell_handle c, int i, int j) const
memberdef.name: incident_cells

briefdescription.para: As above for edge (i,j) of c.
Starts at cell start.

simplesect.para: t.dimension() == 3 and start is incident to e.

memberdef.argsstring: (Cell_handle c, int i, int j, Cell_handle start) const
memberdef.name: incident_cells

briefdescription.para: As above for edge (i,j) of c.

description.para: The following circulators on facets are defined only in dimension 3, though facets are defined also in dimension 2: there are only two facets sharing an edge in dimension 2.

briefdescription.para: Starts at an arbitrary facet incident to e.

memberdef.argsstring: (Cell_handle c, int i, int j) const
memberdef.name: incident_facets

briefdescription.para: As above for edge (i,j) of c.
Starts at facet start.

simplesect.para: start is incident to e.

memberdef.argsstring: (Edge e, Cell_handle start, int f) const
memberdef.name: incident_facets

briefdescription.para: Starts at facet of index f in start.

memberdef.argsstring: (Cell_handle c, int i, int j, Facet start) const
memberdef.name: incident_facets

briefdescription.para: As above for edge (i,j) of c.

memberdef.argsstring: (Cell_handle c, int i, int j, Cell_handle start, int f) const
memberdef.name: incident_facets

briefdescription.para: As above for edge (i,j) of c and facet (start,f).

sectiondef.header: Traversal of the Incident Cells, Facets and Edges, and the Adjacent Vertices of a Given Vertex

briefdescription.para: Copies the Cell_handles of all cells incident to v to the output iterator cells.

detaileddescription.para:
Returns the resulting output iterator.
t.dimension() == 3, v != Vertex_handle(), t.is_vertex(v).

briefdescription.para: Try to lock and copy the Cell_handles of all cells incident to v into cells.

detaileddescription.para: Returns true in case of success. Otherwise, cells is emptied and the function returns false. In any case, the locked cells are not unlocked by try_lock_and_get_incident_cells(), leaving this choice to the user.

simplesect.para: t.dimension() == 3, v != Vertex_handle(), t.is_vertex(v).

briefdescription.para: Copies the Cell_handles of all finite cells incident to v to the output iterator cells.

detaileddescription.para:
Returns the resulting output iterator.
t.dimension() == 3, v != Vertex_handle(), t.is_vertex(v).

briefdescription.para: Copies all Facets incident to v to the output iterator facets.

detaileddescription.para:
Returns the resulting output iterator.
t.dimension() > 1, v != Vertex_handle(), t.is_vertex(v).

briefdescription.para: Copies all finite Facets incident to v to the output iterator facets.

detaileddescription.para:
Returns the resulting output iterator.
t.dimension() > 1, v != Vertex_handle(), t.is_vertex(v).

briefdescription.para: Copies all Edges incident to v to the output iterator edges.

detaileddescription.para:
Returns the resulting output iterator.
t.dimension() > 0, v != Vertex_handle(), t.is_vertex(v).

briefdescription.para: Copies all finite Edges incident to v to the output iterator edges.

detaileddescription.para:
Returns the resulting output iterator.
t.dimension() > 0, v != Vertex_handle(), t.is_vertex(v).

briefdescription.para: Copies the Vertex_handles of all vertices adjacent to v to the output iterator vertices.

detaileddescription.para:
If t.dimension() < 0, then do nothing. Returns the resulting output iterator.
v != Vertex_handle(), t.is_vertex(v).

briefdescription.para: Copies the Vertex_handles of all finite vertices adjacent to v to the output iterator vertices.

detaileddescription.para:
If t.dimension() < 0, then do nothing. Returns the resulting output iterator.
v != Vertex_handle(), t.is_vertex(v).

briefdescription.para: Returns the degree of a vertex, that is, the number of incident vertices.

detaileddescription.para:
The infinite vertex is counted.
v != Vertex_handle(), t.is_vertex(v).

briefdescription.para: Returns the index of c in its $ i^{th}$ neighbor.
Returns the vertex of the $ i^{th}$ neighbor of c that is opposite to c.
Returns the same facet seen from the other adjacent cell.

description.para: The responsibility of keeping a valid triangulation belongs to the user when using advanced operations allowing a direct manipulation of cells and vertices.
We provide the user with the following methods to help debugging.

briefdescription.para: This is a function for debugging purpose.

detaileddescription.para: Checks the combinatorial validity of the triangulation. Checks also the validity of its geometric embedding (see Section Representation). When verbose is set to true, messages describing the first invalidity encountered are printed.

briefdescription.para: This is a function for debugging purpose.

detaileddescription.para: Checks the combinatorial validity of the cell by calling the is_valid method of the cell class. Also checks the geometric validity of c, if c is finite. (See Section Representation.)
When verbose is set to true, messages are printed to give a precise indication of the kind of invalidity encountered.

description.para: CGAL provides an interface to Geomview for a 3D-triangulation, see Chapter Chapter_Geomview on Geomview_stream.

The information in the iostream is: the dimension, the number of finite vertices, the non-combinatorial information about vertices (point, etc; note that the infinite vertex is numbered 0), the number of cells, the indices of the vertices of each cell, plus the non-combinatorial information about each cell, then the indices of the neighbors of each cell, where the index corresponds to the preceding list of cells. When dimension $ <$ 3, the same information is stored for faces of maximal dimension instead of cells.

briefdescription.para: Reads the underlying combinatorial triangulation from is by calling the corresponding input operator of the triangulation data structure class (note that the infinite vertex is numbered 0), and the non-combinatorial information by calling the corresponding input operators of the vertex and the cell classes (such as point coordinates), which are provided by overloading the stream operators of the vertex and cell types.

detaileddescription.para: Assigns the resulting triangulation to t.

briefdescription.para: Writes the triangulation t into os.
Set the pointer to the lock data structure.
The enum Locate_type is defined by Triangulation_3 to specify which case occurs when locating a point in the triangulation.
The class Triangulation_3 represents a 3-dimensional tetrahedralization of points.

parameterdescription.para: is the geometric traits class and must be a model of TriangulationTraits_3.

is the triangulation data structure and must be a model of TriangulationDataStructure_3. Default may be used, with default type Triangulation_data_structure_3<Triangulation_vertex_base_3<Traits>, Triangulation_cell_base_3<Traits> >. Any custom type can be used instead of Triangulation_vertex_base_3 and Triangulation_cell_base_3, provided that they are models of the concepts TriangulationVertexBase_3 and TriangulationCellBase_3, respectively.

is an optional parameter to specify the type of the spatial lock data structure. It must be a model of the SurjectiveLockDataStructure concept, with Object being a Point (as defined below). It is only used if the triangulation data structure used is concurrency-safe (i.e. when TriangulationDataStructure_3::Concurrency_tag is Parallel_tag). The default value is Spatial_lock_grid_3<Tag_priority_blocking> if the triangulation data structure is concurrency-safe, and void otherwise. In order to use concurrent operations, the user must provide a reference to a SLDS instance via the constructor or Triangulation_3::set_lock_data_structure.

detaileddescription.para: The triangulation class provides several iterators and circulators that allow one to traverse it (completely or partially).

node.label: CGAL::Triangulation_3< Traits, Delaunay_triangulation_3< Traits, TDS, LP >::Triangulation_data_structure, SLDS >
